s.text: Richard Shelby, R-Ala., concluded, "I'm not sure we have the will to win."
A true idealist would lobby the coalition hard for ground troops, as British Prime Minister Tony Blair has done, or would jettison the coalition and send in his own ground troops anyway.
Instead, the Clinton team accepts the coalition's reluctance and tells us this is just the way things are.

The other puzzle is the incoherence of Clinton's critics, punctuated by DeLay's bizarre complaint that Clinton has 1) "hollowed out our forces while he's running around having these adventures all over the world"; and 2) fallen short of "victory" in Kosovo by using "excessive rhetoric supported by underwhelming force" in a conflict involving "no strategic interest of the United States."
As long as Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic is willing to withstand airstrikes, "there is no real end in sight," former Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger cautioned this weekend.

Realism tempers the romanticism of idealists with a sense of tragedy.
Realists regard Serbian resistance to NATO as a fact of life, an immovable constraint on American ambitions in the Balkans.
And what about the hundreds of civilians killed by errant NATO bombs?
Even if we stopped killings everywhere, we couldn't do so without killing people ourselves.

Thursday, in what many deemed a slap at--and arguably an oversimplification of--the theories of Balkans scholar Robert D. Kaplan and Holocaust scholar Daniel Jonah Goldhagen, Clinton repudiated those who "justify looking away from this kind of slaughter ...

No, said Cohen, but "Milosevic is going to find that his military forces are systematically being diminished at a time when the KLA will come back," since it is "getting money and support and some arms from other countries, no doubt."

"It's because he's determined that we have to be determined as well," NATO spokesman Jamie Shea argued on Late Edition . On Face the Nation , host Bob Schieffer skeptically asked Defense Secretary William Cohen, "How long are you prepared to do this?"
When asked this weekend why the United States was withholding helicopters, Joint Chiefs Chairman Gen.

But five days later, when asked why the United States was refusing to send Apache helicopters and ground troops into Kosovo, Clinton cited prudence, objective difficulties, and the "risk" to American soldiers.
